text: Can anyone point me in the direction of the documentation on how to generate SLL certificates for API access? I've recently upgraded to ubuntu 22.04 which apparently uses SSL 3 and no longer allows lowering security. I always got around this on earlier versions using a local openssl.cnf as described <https://askubuntu.com/questions/1233186/ubuntu-20-04-how-to-set-lower-ssl-security-level>  but this no longer works so I think I want to bite the bullet and generate some new certificates. As a side question, I am assuming that we can generate as many or as few SSL cert files as we like for our accounts?

attachments.fallback: Ask Ubuntu: Ubuntu 20.04 - how to set lower SSL security level?
attachments.text:
I'd like to ask if there's a way to lower SSL security level to 1 on Ubuntu 20.04, since I'm receiving:

141A318A:SSL routines:tls_process_ske_dhe:dh key too small
when trying to curl the website....
attachments.title: Ubuntu 20.04 - how to set lower SSL security level?

elements.text: Can anyone point me in the direction of the documentation on how to generate SLL certificates for API access? I've recently upgraded to ubuntu 22.04 which apparently uses SSL 3 and no longer allows lowering security. I always got around this on earlier versions using a local openssl.cnf as described

but this no longer works so I think I want to bite the bullet and generate some new certificates. As a side question, I am assuming that we can generate as many or as few SSL cert files as we like for our accounts?

text: As far as I know you just have one certificate that is linked to your account <https://docs.developer.betfair.com/display/1smk3cen4v3lu3yomq5qye0ni/Non-Interactive+%28bot%29+login>

elements.text: As far as I know you just have one certificate that is linked to your account

text: Yeah I worked it out eventually - but you can have multiple certs added to your account. I mailed bdp and they confirmed this. Uploaded a new one and it works fine but more importantly so does the existing one. Much better than farting about editing openssl config files.

elements.text: Yeah I worked it out eventually - but you can have multiple certs added to your account. I mailed bdp and they confirmed this. Uploaded a new one and it works fine but more importantly so does the existing one. Much better than farting about editing openssl config files.
